Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Propagation systems for generation of chromosomally stable human embryonic stem cells

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
0744556
Rao

The intellectual merit of this project is the development of an integrated ex vivo system for propagation of chromosomally stable human embryonic stem cells (hESCs), and for relating gene transcription to specific microenvironmental conditions. The ex vivo propagation system developed as part of this project will meet specific expectations that aim to (i) be efficient, producing high densities and quantities of pluripotent cells; (ii) maintain stem cells? genotypic and phenotypic integrity over several generations; and finally, (iii) use only defined, animal-product free culture components.

The techniques, tools and mindset required to accomplish this research program require an overlap of interdisciplinary engineering, molecular genetics and cellular biology skills. The Principal Investigator (PI) plans to increase the awareness of the power of these interdisciplinary skills by developing educational modules for students at a variety of educational levels. By working with high school teachers, public educators at museums, and faculty at primarily undergraduate universities, the PI will develop presentation and laboratory modules that will benefit high school students, undergraduate students and the general public. The broader impacts of this project are the enormous potential for communicating research findings to a wider audience and for students and the general public to get excited about the latest advances in stem cell research.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Human pluripotent stem cells that include human embryonic stem cells and human induced pluripotent stem cells have gained enormous interest as potential sources for regenerative biomedical therapies, model systems for studying early human development and for use in drug discovery. Optimizing culture conditions that reduce genomic instability in human pluripotent stem cell cultures is an unmet challenge in the field. Prior results from our lab and numerous research groups demonstrate that human stem cells are prone to genomic aberrations. Research findings from this project demonstrate the importance of developing defined bio-inspired materials for propagating stem cells that not only maintain their undifferentiated state but also their genomic stability. Equally important research findings include the identification and characterization of novel genes that could contribute to generation and/or survival of abnormal stem cells. The intellectual merit of these research findings contribute to the development of controlled microenvironments for propagation of stable stem cells for potential clinical applications. These studies will also aid in the long-term goal of scaling up human pluripotent stem cell production while promoting stable propagation of genomically normal stem cells. The broader impact of this project has been the education and interdisciplinary training of students at a variety of educational levels and the dissemination of research findings to a wide audience.


Last Modified: 08/08/2014
Modified by: Raj R Rao
